bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to [s.n.] Mitten, November 3, 1941

div1.p: Andrus discusses the yellow fever experiments and the role played by Lambert, whom he feels deserves more credit.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to [s.n.] Mitten, November 3, 1941
div1.opener:
Andrus letter
FROM GUST LAMBERT
11-3-41
Dear Friend Mitten:
div1.p:
I want you to know that I greatly appreciate the spirit of
friendship which actuated you in offering to send me a
print of Dean Cornwell's painting, “The Conquest of Yellow
Fever.”

A framed, autographed engravers' proof was sent me by
Mr. Kellogg in recognition, I suppose, for my efforts to help
with technical advice and photographs furnished while the
work was in process.

Mr. Kellogg visited me on two occasions, sent me quite a
number of photostats covering different stages of development
and there was quite a volume of correspondence.

If you have no use for the print you obtained for me and do
not want it yourself, I can tell you where it will be very
much appreciated.

The man who nursed me-and all other experimental yellow fever
cases-as a member of the Army Hospital Corps, has never been
given the recognition he deserves.

He is: Gust. E. Lambert
4718 Woodlawn Ave.,
Chicago, Ill.

I have done everything I know how to do to have Lambert's
services recognized and rewarded and, on several occasions,
bills to that effect have passed the Senate only to.be killed
in the House...

You had been away from the Whiz outfit for some time before
I learned of it. I do not see anyone from there very often
which is not remarkable when it is considered that I have been
out for nearly ten years.

I earnestly hope that your present connection affords greater
scope for your talents and that it is both pleasant and
profitable.
With kindest regards and all good wishes,
